Title: Every finite subgroup of $\mathbb{Q}/\mathbb{Z}$ is cyclic
Content: Show that every finite subgroup of the quotient group $\mathbb{Q}/\mathbb{Z}$ (under addition) is cyclic. Note: there is a related problem which I just proved: "Let $G$ be a finite abelian group, then $G$ is non-cyclic iff $G$ has a subgroup isomorphic to $C_p \times C_p$ for some prime $p$." Since $\mathbb{Q} /\mathbb{Z}$ is abelian, so based on the related problem it suffices to show it has no elementary abelian subgroup group. I tried to start prove by contradiction: Let $\mathbb{Z} <A<\mathbb{Q}$ such that $A$/$\mathbb{Z} \simeq C_p \oplus C_p$ for some prime p, but I can't proceed further.
AcceptedAnswer: Not in the direction you wish but you can identify $\mathbb{Q}/\mathbb{Z}$ as a subgroup of the complex numbers: $\mathbb{Q}/\mathbb{Z} < \mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z} \cong S^1 \subset \mathbb C^\times$, and then use that every finite multiplicative subgroup of a field is cyclic.

The user mentioned a related problem about finite abelian groups being non-cyclic if they have a subgroup isomorphic to C_p × C_p for some prime p. Since ℚ/ℤ is abelian, the idea is to show it has no such elementary abelian subgroups, which would imply every finite subgroup is cyclic.

First, I need to recall what ℚ/ℤ looks like. Elements of ℚ/ℤ are cosets of the form q + ℤ where q is a rational number. The group operation is addition modulo 1. So, for example, 1/2 + 1/2 = 0 in this group because 1/2 + 1/2 = 1, which is equivalent to 0 modulo ℤ.

Now, any finite subgroup of ℚ/ℤ must consist of elements of finite order. That makes sense because in a quotient group, the order of an element q + ℤ is the smallest positive integer n such that nq is an integer. So, every element in a finite subgroup must have order dividing some integer n, which would mean all elements can be written with denominators dividing n.

Suppose H is a finite subgroup of ℚ/ℤ. Then, all elements in H can be represented by fractions with denominators dividing some common n. That is, H is isomorphic to a subgroup of the group generated by 1/n + ℤ. Wait, but the group generated by 1/n is cyclic of order n. So, if all elements in H have order dividing n, then H is a subgroup of a cyclic group of order n, which is itself cyclic. Because every subgroup of a cyclic group is cyclic.

But the user is suggesting an approach via contradiction: assuming there's a subgroup isomorphic to C_p × C_p. Let me think. If H is a finite subgroup of ℚ/ℤ, suppose H is not cyclic. Then, by the related problem, H would have a subgroup isomorphic to C_p × C_p for some prime p. So, we need to show this can't happen.

Suppose for contradiction that there exists a prime p and a subgroup K of ℚ/ℤ such that K ≅ C_p × C_p. Then, K has p² elements, all of order p. So, in ℚ/ℤ, there are two distinct elements x + ℤ and y + ℤ, both of order p, such that the subgroup generated by them is isomorphic to C_p × C_p. That would mean that the orders of x and y are p, and they are linearly independent over ℤ, meaning no nontrivial combination gives an integer.

But in ℚ/ℤ, elements of order p must be of the form a/p + ℤ where a is an integer not divisible by p. So, x = a/p + ℤ and y = b/p + ℤ for some integers a, b not divisible by p. Then, the subgroup generated by x and y would consist of all elements (ka/p + lb/p) + ℤ for k, l integers. But since we are in ℚ/ℤ, adding these would give (ka + lb)/p + ℤ. However, since a and b are invertible modulo p (because they're not divisible by p), the set {ka + lb | k, l ∈ ℤ} modulo p would generate all residues modulo p. Therefore, the subgroup generated by x and y would actually be cyclic, because any element can be written as c/p + ℤ for some c, which is a single generator. Contradiction. Hence, there can't be two independent elements of order p, so C_p × C_p cannot be a subgroup. Therefore, every finite subgroup must be cyclic.

So, putting this together, the key point is that in ℚ/ℤ, any two elements of order p generate a cyclic group, not a direct product. Hence, there can be no elementary abelian subgroups of rank 2, so every finite subgroup must be cyclic.
